segment.source: System objects Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems (Windows 10)
segment.target: System objects Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System objects Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System objects Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems security policy setting.

segment.source: System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems
segment.target: System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines whether case insensitivity is enforced for all subsystems.
segment.target: This policy setting determines whether case insensitivity is enforced for all subsystems.

segment.source: The Microsoft Win32 subsystem is not case sensitive; however, the kernel supports case sensitivity for other subsystems, such as Portable Operating System Interface for UNIX (POSIX).
segment.target: The Microsoft Win32 subsystem is not case sensitive; however, the kernel supports case sensitivity for other subsystems, such as Portable Operating System Interface for UNIX (POSIX).

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting enforces case insensitivity for all directory objects, symbolic links, and input/output (I/O) objects, including file objects.
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting enforces case insensitivity for all directory objects, symbolic links, and input/output (I/O) objects, including file objects.

segment.source: Disabling this policy setting does not allow the Win32 subsystem to become case sensitive.
segment.target: Disabling this policy setting does not allow the Win32 subsystem to become case sensitive.

segment.source: Because Windows is case insensitive but the POSIX subsystem will support case sensitivity, if this policy setting is not enforced, it is possible for a user of that subsystem to create a file with the same name as another file but with a different mix of capital letters.
segment.target: Because Windows is case insensitive but the POSIX subsystem will support case sensitivity, if this policy setting is not enforced, it is possible for a user of that subsystem to create a file with the same name as another file but with a different mix of capital letters.

segment.source: That might confuse users when they try to access these files by using normal Win32 tools, because only one of the files will be available.
segment.target: That might confuse users when they try to access these files by using normal Win32 tools, because only one of the files will be available.

segment.source: Case insensitivity is enforced for all directory objects, symbolic links, and IO objects, including file objects.
segment.target: Case insensitivity is enforced for all directory objects, symbolic links, and IO objects, including file objects.

segment.source: Will not allow the Win32 subsystem to become case sensitive.
segment.target: Will not allow the Win32 subsystem to become case sensitive.

segment.source: All subsystems will be forced to observe case insensitivity.
segment.target: All subsystems will be forced to observe case insensitivity.

segment.source: However, this might confuse users who are familiar with one of the UNIX-based operating systems and are used to a case sensitive operating system.
segment.target: However, this might confuse users who are familiar with one of the UNIX-based operating systems and are used to a case sensitive operating system.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Because Windows is case insensitive but the POSIX subsystem supports case sensitivity, failure to enable this policy setting makes it possible for a user of that subsystem to create a file with the same name as another file but with a different mix of uppercase and lowercase letters.
segment.target: Because Windows is case insensitive but the POSIX subsystem supports case sensitivity, failure to enable this policy setting makes it possible for a user of that subsystem to create a file with the same name as another file but with a different mix of uppercase and lowercase letters.

segment.source: Such a situation could potentially confuse users when they try to access such files from normal Win32 tools because only one of the files is available.
segment.target: Such a situation could potentially confuse users when they try to access such files from normal Win32 tools because only one of the files is available.

segment.source: Enable the System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems setting.
segment.target: Enable the System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems setting.

segment.source: All subsystems are forced to observe case insensitivity.
segment.target: All subsystems are forced to observe case insensitivity.

segment.source: This configuration may confuse users who are familiar with any UNIX-based operating systems that are case sensitive.
segment.target: This configuration may confuse users who are familiar with any UNIX-based operating systems that are case sensitive.
